questions.question: Which office skills concepts would be nice for me to adopt before starting my dentistry job?
questions.answer:
If you are preparing to start your dentistry job, it would be beneficial to focus on enhancing your communicative competencies. Effective communication is essential in the field of dentistry for interacting with patients, explaining treatment plans, and collaborating with colleagues.

To learn more about how to showcase your communicative competencies in your professional life, you can refer to the following article: https://cvapp.de/blog/kommunikative-faehigkeiten

Would you like to explore additional resources on improving your communication skills for your upcoming dentistry job?

questions.question: how to know is dentisry is right for me ? how to know our strenghts?
questions.answer:
To assess if dentistry is the right career path for you and identify your strengths, you can start by evaluating your individual self-efficacy expectations. Self-efficacy refers to your belief in your ability to succeed in specific situations or accomplish tasks. 

You can take a self-test to get an initial sense of your self-efficacy expectations by visiting the following link: https://instahelp.me/de/selbsttest/selbstwirksamkeit/

Additionally, you can read the blog entry by the work psychologist and science blogger Mario Schuster, which elaborates on the influences shaping our self-efficacy expectations: https://www.mental-blog.com/mentalblog_synergy/selbstwirksamkeit-quellen/

Would you like to explore more resources on self-efficacy and identifying your strengths for determining if dentistry is the right fit for you?

questions.question: whats iceberg communication model?
questions.answer:
The Iceberg Communication Model is a metaphorical representation of the human mind and behavior, popularized by the Austrian-American psychologist Sigmund Freud. The model compares the human mind to an iceberg, where only a small portion is visible above the water surface (consciousness), while the majority remains hidden beneath the surface.

Key concepts of the Iceberg Model include:
1. Consciousness (Surface): This is the visible part of the iceberg above the water surface, containing thoughts, feelings, and actions that a person is aware of.
2. Subconscious (Below the Water Surface): Represents what a person is not directly aware of but still influences their behavior, including memories, wishes, impulses, and other aspects not present in current consciousness.
3. Preconscious (Partially Visible Above the Water Surface): This area lies between consciousness and the subconscious, containing information that can easily enter consciousness when needed but may not always be actively present.

The Iceberg Model explains that many psychological processes and influences occur beneath the surface of our consciousness, impacting our behavior without us being fully aware of them. It emphasizes that what we see and understand is only a small part of what is happening in our minds.

If you want to delve deeper into the Iceberg Communication Model, you can explore the following link: https://moodle.hm.edu/course/view.php?id=1006860#coursecontentcollapse2

Would you like to learn more about the applications of the Iceberg Model in communication theory?
